PROGRAM agc046_b
   IMPLICIT NONE
   integer*8, parameter :: mod=998244353
   integer :: max_dim=3000
   integer*8 :: dp(0:3000, 0:3000)
   integer :: A,B,C,D

   read *, A,B,C,D

   ! initialize starting value:

      do d = B, D

         term2=0_8

children.text:
Alternative approach:

Variables can be declared at the level of the loops. Here's the revised code:

program agc046_b
  implicit none
  integer*8, parameter :: mod = 998244353
  integer, parameter :: max_dim=3000
  integer*8 :: dp(0:max_dim, 0:max_dim)
  integer :: A,B,C,D,c,d

  read(*,*) A,B,C,D
  dp = 0_8
  dp(A,B)=1_8

  do c = A, C
    do d = B, D
      if( c == A .and. d == B ) cycle

      integer*8 :: ans, t1, t2, t3
      ans = 0_8
      t1 = 0_8
      t2 = 0_8
      t3 = 0_8

      if(c > A) t1 = dp(c-1,d)*d
      if(d > B) t2 = dp(c,d-1)*c
      if( c > A .and. d > B ) t3 = dp(c-1,d-1)*(c-1)*(d-1)

      ans = t1 + t2 - t3
      dp(c,d) = mod(ans,mod)

    end do
  end do

  write(*,*)
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
dp(C,D)
end program

children.text: Changing the parameter's name to avoid collision. Ah right, that's a problem!

children.text: Because Fortran has a built-in function called mod(...), so the variable named "mod" would conflict.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Bad decision to name it MOD if uppercase in Java, but in Fortran parameters are case-insensitive by default (unless configured otherwise). So the best is to choose a different name for the MOD constant. Like:

change 

integer*8, parameter :: MODPARAM=998244353

and use MODPARAM throughout.
children.label: bug_fixing

children.text:
Or use all uppercase: MOD as a parameter, but then need to use function as mod. But since the intrinsic function is named MOD, we can have a parameter with the same name (if uppercase on case-insensitive systems), but better to change. Thus, correct code:

 changing MOD to MOD_ in code:

program agc046_b
  implicit none
  integer*8, parameter :: MOD_ =998244353
  integer, parameter :: max_dim =3000
  integer*8 :: dp(0:max_dim, 0:max_dim)
  integer :: A,B,C,D,c,d

  read(*,*) A,B,C,D
  dp =0_8
  dp(A,B) =1_8

  do c = A, C
    do d = B, D
      if (c ==A .and. d == B ) cycle

      integer*8 :: ans, t1,t2,t3
      ans =0_8; t1=0_8; t2=0_8; t3=0_8

      if(c >A) then
          t1 = dp(c-1,d) * d
      end if
      if(d>B) then
          t2 = dp(c, d-1)*c
      end if
      if( c>A .and. d> B ) then
          t3 = dp(c-1,d-1)* (c-1)*(d-1)
      end if

      ans = t1 + t2 - t3 

      dp(c,d) = modulo( ans, MOD_ )
children.label: bug_fixing

end do
  end do

  write(*,'(I0)') dp(C,D)
end program I think this should work now.

Now putting it all together.

Now the skeleton:

PROGRAM agc046_b
   IMPLICIT NONE
   integer*8, parameter :: mod=998244353
   integer :: max_dim=3000
   integer*8 :: dp(0:3000, 0:3000)
   integer :: A,B,C,D

   read *, A,B,C,D
   dp = 0_8
   ! initialize starting value:
   dp(A,B) = 1_8 

   do c = A, C
      do d = B, D
         if (c ==A .and. d==B) cycle  ! skip the first one
         integer*8 :: ans, term1, term2, term3
         ans = 0_8
         term1=0_8
         term2=0_8
         term3=0_8

         if( c > A ) then
             term1 = dp(c-1,d) * d
         end if

         if (d > B) then
             term2 = dp(c,d-1) * c
         end if

         if ( c > A .and. d > B ) then
             term3 = dp(c-1,d-1) * (c-1)*(d-1)
         end if 
         ans = term1 + term2 - term3 

         dp(c,d) = modulo(ans, mod)
      end do
   end do
   print *, dp(C,D)
END PROGRAM

Alternative approach:

Variables can be declared at the level of the loops. Here's the revised code:

program agc046_b
  implicit none
  integer*8, parameter :: mod = 998244353
  integer, parameter :: max_dim=3000
  integer*8 :: dp(0:max_dim, 0:max_dim)
  integer :: A,B,C,D,c,d

  read(*,*) A,B,C,D
  dp = 0_8
  dp(A,B)=1_8

  do c = A, C
    do d = B, D
      if( c == A .and. d == B ) cycle

      integer*8 :: ans, t1, t2, t3
      ans = 0_8
      t1 = 0_8
      t2 = 0_8
      t3 = 0_8

      if(c > A) t1 = dp(c-1,d)*d
      if(d > B) t2 = dp(c,d-1)*c
      if( c > A .and. d > B ) t3 = dp(c-1,d-1)*(c-1)*(d-1)

      ans = t1 + t2 - t3
      dp(c,d) = mod(ans,mod)

    end do
  end do

  write(*,*) dp(C,D)
end program

Wait in the code above, I wrote:

dp(c,d) = mod(ans, mod). Hmm, no, mod in the function is modulo.

 Correction:

The code in the sample uses 'mod' for the parameter, which might conflict with Fortran's intrinsic mod function. Changing the parameter's name to avoid collision.

Ah right, that's a problem! 

Because Fortran has a built-in function called mod(...), so the variable named "mod" would conflict. Bad decision to name it MOD if uppercase in Java, but in Fortran parameters are case-insensitive by default (unless configured otherwise). 

So the best is to choose a different name for the MOD constant. Like:

change 

integer*8, parameter :: MODPARAM=998244353

and use MODPARAM throughout.

Or use all uppercase: MOD as a parameter, but then need to use function as mod.

 But since the intrinsic function is named MOD, we can have a parameter with the same name (if uppercase on case-insensitive systems), but better to change.

Thus, correct code:

 changing MOD to MOD_ in code:

program agc046_b
  implicit none
  integer*8, parameter :: MOD_ =998244353
  integer, parameter :: max_dim =3000
  integer*8 :: dp(0:max_dim, 0:max_dim)
  integer :: A,B,C,D,c,d

  read(*,*) A,B,C,D
  dp =0_8
  dp(A,B) =1_8

  do c = A, C
    do d = B, D
      if (c ==A .and. d == B ) cycle

      integer*8 :: ans, t1,t2,t3
      ans =0_8; t1=0_8; t2=0_8; t3=0_8

      if(c >A) then
          t1 = dp(c-1,d) * d
      end if
      if(d>B) then
          t2 = dp(c, d-1)*c
      end if
      if( c>A .and. d> B ) then
          t3 = dp(c-1,d-1)* (c-1)*(d-1)
      end if

      ans = t1 + t2 - t3 

      dp(c,d) = modulo( ans, MOD_ )
    end do
  end do

  write(*,'(I0)') dp(C,D)
end program 

I think this should work now.

Testing possible boundaries:

Assume that A,B are both zero, but that's possibly within the problem's constraints. But the problem's sample input might handle.

Another thing to note:

When A > C, e.g, if A=5, C=3, then C is smaller, but in the loop, the c loop from A to C would do it only if C >=A.

So need to handle that the input is correct (as per problem's requirements). The code may assume that inputs are in order A <=C and B <= D.

Other possible typos: in the term3 computation, multiplying (c-1) and (d-1). The code has correct syntax.

Thus this should be correct.
